review.title: NNVLP: A Neural Network-Based Vietnamese Language Processing Toolkit
review.abstract: This paper demonstrates neural network-based toolkit namely NNVLP for essential Vietnamese language processing tasks including part-of-speech (POS) tagging, chunking, Named Entity Recognition (NER). Our toolkit is a combination of bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM), Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), Conditional Random Field (CRF), using pre-trained word embeddings as input, which outperforms previously published toolkits on these three tasks. We provide both API and web demo for this toolkit.

metadata.title: NNVLP: A Neural Network-Based Vietnamese Language Processing Toolkit

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Vietnamese is one of the 20 most widely spoken languages and is used by an important community around the world. Therefore, research into Vietnamese language processing is an essential task. This work focuses on three main tasks for processing Vietnamese language, including POS tagging, chunking and NER. In this work, we present a state-of-the-art system, namely NNVLP for processing Vietnamese language. NNVLP toolkit outperforms previously released toolkits for three tasks, including POS tagging, chunking and NER.1nnvlp.orgOur model is a combination of Bi-LSTM, CNN and CRF models that achieve state-of-the-art performance for processing Vietnamese language, including POS tagging, chunking and NER.1nnvlp.orgOur model is a combination of Bi-LSTM, CNN and CRF models that deliver an accuracy of 1.30%, F1-1.837% and 1.911% for Tagking architecture.

sections.heading: 2 Related Works
sections.text: Previous Vietnamese language processing systems used traditional methods of machine learning such as conditional random field (CRF), maximum entropy markov model (MEMM) and support vector machine (SVM). Specifically, most POS tagging toolkits attempted to use traditional models such as CRF (Mai-Vu Tran, 2013) and MEMM (Le-Hong et al., 2010). (Mai-Vu Tran, 2013) also used CRF for chunking tasks. Recently, at the VLSP 2016 workshop on NER tasks, several participating systems used MEMM (Le-Hong, 2016), (Nguyen et al., 2016) and CRF (Le et al., 2016) to solve this problem.

sections.heading: 3.1 System Architecture
sections.text: We implement the deep neural network model described in (Pham and Le-Hong, 2017). Thisar Xiv: 170 8.07 241v 1 [cs.C L] 24 Aug 201 7model is a combination of Bi-directional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM), Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Conditional Random Field (CRF). Specifically, this model takes as input a sequence of concatenation of word embeddings trained by word2vec2 tool and word characteristics at character level. This sequence is then passed on to a Bi-LSTM, and then a CRF layer takes the sequence of the BiLSTM as input to predict the best named word embedding sequence. Figure 1 and Figure 2 describe the architectures of the BI-LSTM-CRF layers and the CNN layer respectively. sections.heading: 3.2 NNVLP API
sections.text: NNVLP API is a Vietnamese language processing API that accepts input records and prints a JSON with a list of sentences in which each word in these sentences has POS tag, chunk, and named entity attributes, as shown in Figure 4.3https: / / pypi.python.org / pypi / pyvi.

sections.heading: 3.3 Web Demo
sections.text: We also offer Web Interface4 for users of the NNVLP toolkit. Users can enter or paste raw text into the text field and click the Submit button to get the corresponding POS tags, chunks and named entity sequences. Each label is provided with a different color to make the output easy to see. Users can also look up the meaning of each label by clicking the Help button. Figure 5 represents the web interface of our system.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: In this section, we compare the performance of the NNVLP toolkit with other published toolkits for Vietnamese, including Vitk5, Vtools6 and RDRPOSTagger7.

sections.heading: 4.1 Data Sets
sections.text: In order to make a fair comparison, we train and evaluate these systems against the VLSP corpora. In particular, we conduct experiments on the Viet Treebank corpus for POS tagging and chunking tasks, and on the VLSP corpus 2016 for NER tasks. All these corpus are converted to the CoNLL format. The corpus of the POS tagging task consists of two columns, namely Word and POS tag. For chunking tasks, there are three columns, namely Word, POS tag and chunking records in the corpus. The core of the NER task consists of four columns. The order of these columns is word, POS tag, chunk and designated entity. While the NER corpus has been separated into training and examination parts, the POS tagging and chunking records are not split up beforehand. Therefore, we use 80% of these data sets as training sets and the rest of our training set as our NP method, as we use the Early Date.

sections.heading: 4.3 Experiment Results
sections.text: We evaluate the performance of our system and multiple published systems for POS tagging, chunking, and NER records. Inputs for POS tagging tasks are words, words and POS tags for chunking tasks, and words, POS tags, and chunks for NER tasks. Table 3, Table 4, and Table 5 present the performance of each system for POS tagging, chunking, and NER tasks accordingly. By combining bidirectional short-term memory, revolutionary neural network, and conditional random field, our system outperforms all published systems for these three tasks. Specifically, the NNVLP toolkit achieves an accuracy of 91.30%, F1 values of 84.11%, and 91.37% for POS tagging, chunking, and NER tasks, respectively.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We introduce a neural network-based Vietnamese language processing toolkit that is a combination of Bi-LSTM, CNN, and CRF. Using raw sentences as input, the system outputs JSON, which contains a list of sentences in which each word in these sentences has POS tag, chunk, and named entity attributes. Experimental results showed that the NNVLP toolkit outperforms previous toolkits in three tasks, including POS tagging, chunking, and NER.
